descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Hidayet Turkoglu scored a career-high 24 points to lead the Sacramento Kings to a 109-106 overtime victory over the San Antonio Spurs on Friday night.
article.headline: Turkoglu's career-high 24 lifts Kings in Alamodome

images.name: Turkoglu, Hidayet 011130 inline
images.caption: Sacramento's Hidayet Turkoglo had a career-high 24 points against the Spurs.

article.linkText: Kings win in San Antonio as Turkoglu shines
article.story:
SAN ANTONIO (AP) -- The Sacramento Kings are getting contributions from different players almost every game. Hidayet Turkoglu came off the bench and scored a career-high 24 points to lead the Kings to a 109-106 overtime victory over the San Antonio Spurs on Friday night. Mike Bibby added 22 points, and Lawrence Funderburke a season-high 16 for Sacramento, which won its third straight. Predrag Stojakovic, who came in averaging 24.3 points, was held to only 11. "Our guys have been playing with a new determination," said Sacramento coach Rick Adelman, whose team improved to 13-4 this season without injured All-Star forward Chris Webber. The Kings completed a sweep of their Texas road trip, with wins earlier this week against Houston and Dallas. "They understand that other players have to step up," Adelman continued. "We've been playing with a large amount of energy. They just believe that they can win. If you would have told me at this point in the season we would be 13-4, it would have been hard to believe. Now it doesn't matter who we play, they just believe they can win. And that attitude has rubbed off on me." San Antonio, which fell to 7-1 at the Alamodome this season, was led by a season-high 38 points from Tim Duncan. Antonio Daniels added 14 points, while David Robinson, Steve Smith and Terry Porter scored 10 points each. "It was a very physical game, a good game," San Antonio coach Gregg Popovich said. "Both teams went after each other in that sense. Down the stretch our execution was not as sharp as it should be. That hurt us down the stretch." Duncan's bank shot gave San Antonio a two-point lead in overtime, but Sacramento answered with an 8-0 run to lead 105-99 on Bobby Jackson's two free throws with 27.4 seconds to play. Smith made a 3-pointer to cut the lead to 105-102 with 25.4 remaining. But it was as close as San Antonio could get as eight of Sacramento's overtime points came at the free-throw line. "He was terrific," Adelman said of Turkoglu. "He's played well the last two games. He really came in and got us going in the second half. He's a young guy but he is really mature for his age. He stepped it up big for us tonight." San Antonio opened the fourth quarter with a 6-4 run and led 87-79 on Duncan's jump shot with 9:23 to play. Sacramento answered with a 7-0 run and closed the Spurs' lead to 87-86 on Turkoglu's free throw with 6:42 to play. Daniels, who had all of his points in the second half, answered with consecutive baskets, the last a 3-point field goal, which gave San Antonio a 92-86 lead with 5:26 remaining. The Kings took a 96-92 lead on a 10-0 run that was capped by two free throws by Turkoglu with 1:17 to play. Robinson fouled out on the play. A three-point play by Duncan made it 96-95 with 1:06 remaining. Following another free throw by Turkoglu, Duncan tied it 97-97 on a driving bank shot with 12.9 seconds to play. Bibby missed a 20-foot jump shot with 0.3 seconds remaining in regulation. "We can enjoy this great win," said Turkoglu, who scored 11 of his points at the free-throw line. "I tried to take advantage against their big guys. I did my job pretty good I think. I just helped my team tonight." Sacramento has defeated San Antonio three straight times over the last two seasons. "They've been playing well, almost at the top of the league with Webber gone," Duncan said. "They did a great job pushing the ball back up when we made mistakes and they capitalized and we didn't." Behind the shooting of Turkoglu, who had 13 first half points, Sacramento closed the first half with a 13-7 run and led 54-49 at halftime. Duncan had 15 of his points in the first half for San Antonio, which struggled with 10 turnovers during the first 24 minutes. The Kings had earlier scored a 103-83 win over the Spurs on Nov. 4 in Sacramento. "We've got two on them this year," Jackson said. "The last two games we've played them, we've been the better team."

Game notes
In the last 10 meetings between the teams, five have gone to overtime, and nine of them have been decided by six points or less. ... Sacramento has won seven of the last 10 meetings with San Antonio ... The Spurs lead the all-time series 69-46. ... San Antonio fell to 7-1 this season in the Alamodome. ... Sacramento had held its previous 10 opponents under 100 points. ... Tim Duncan's double-double was his 12th of the season and 232nd of his career.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
